item.title: Bulgarians Are Getting the Euro, But Half of Them Don’t Want It
item.description: People are growing more concerned about the potential impact on prices.
item.dc:creator: Slav Okov

media:content.media:description: This picture taken on May 16, 2025 shows people listening the national antem of Bulgaria during a rally against the adoption of the Euro, organized by Vazrazhdane party in the national Palace of Culture in Sofia. Bulgaria is expected to get a green light from Brussels in June to adopt the common European currency, the Euro -- but the prospect is unsettling many citizens. Bulgaria has been trying for years to satisfy the European Central Bank's (ECB) conditions to join the euro zone, and hopes to adopt the common currency in 2026. The far-right has demanded a referendum on keeping the national lev currency, but its requests have been rejected by both parliament and the constitutional court. (Photo by Nikolay DOYCHINOV / AFP) (Photo by NIKOLAY DOYCHINOV/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: South Korea Halts K-Pop Broadcasts Into North to Ease Tensions
item.description: SEOUL, South Korea (AP) — South Korea’s military shut down loudspeakers broadcasting anti-North Korea propaganda along the inter-Korean border on Wednesday, marking the new liberal government’s first concrete step toward easing tensions between the war-divided rivals.
